title: Wilhelm Raabe Literature Prize
text:
The Wilhelm Raabe Literature Prize () is a German literary award established in 2000 by the city of <a href="Braunschweig">Braunschweig</a> and the radio broadcaster <a href="Deutschlandradio">Deutschlandradio</a>. It is named after the 18th-century writer <a href="Wilhelm%20Raabe">Wilhelm Raabe</a> and is awarded for an individual work. The prize sum is 30,000 <a href="euro">euro</a>, making it one of the most significant German literary awards after the <a href="Georg%20B%C3%BCchner%20Prize">Georg Büchner Prize</a> and the <a href="Joseph-Breitbach-Preis">Joseph-Breitbach-Preis</a>.
Recipients.
Source:
Previous Recipients.
The award had until 1990 been known as the Wilhelm Raabe Prize.
